messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Information Request
messages.msgSnippet: I checked the kinko meikan, there are three person of the same name. One  was actually Meiji. This one , I think is late Edo, Hamano school ( I could  have
messages.messageBody:
I checked the kinko meikan, there are three person of the same name. One was
actually Meiji.
This one , I think is late Edo, Hamano school ( I could have translated
Hamano wrong, it's something " no " and Hamano comes to mind )


milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Information Request
messages.msgSnippet: ... I would suggest; 延王齋　春利(kao) ENOUSAI HARUTOSHI (KAO) Granted the sai is quite stylized and this is a pretty fancy form of the character, but
messages.messageBody:
>
> http://jdb-tsuba.tripod.com/
>
>





I would suggest;
延王齋　春利(kao)
ENOUSAI HARUTOSHI (KAO)
Granted the "sai" is quite stylized and this is a pretty fancy form
of the character, but cannot see many others fitting in this spot.
Did not find any Harutoshi with a similar Go listed in Haynes. There
was a Nagayoshi who used Ennensai (延年斉). I would not say Soten,
not sure where it comes from but think Soten would be more pierced
and open. Is the base metal iron? if so then it has been cleaned way
too much...
-t

















>
>>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Information Request
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, I cannot see it in Mozilla, but can in IE7, I think it is a cookie blocker thing, try turning off cookie blocking maybe ?. I concur with Peter, this
messages.messageBody:
Richard, I cannot see it in Mozilla, but can in IE7, I think it is a
cookie blocker thing, try turning off cookie blocking maybe ?.

I concur with Peter, this looks like it has seen many better days. The
partina seems gone for the most part. I wonder if someone has had a go
at cleaning it ?. The seppa dai is almost bare metal, while around the
tree on the right, there is active rust in the tight corners. I wonder
if that tree and the branches above were once covered in Shakudo ?.

This could also be a Aizu Shoami piece though I have not researched the
mei. The first two kanji on the right look to read Teiô but the third
has me beat.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba Information Request
messages.msgSnippet: Others will be of more help, but your tsuba is signed HARUTOSHI . It looks like Soten work, but it is in very sad condition with the entire original iron
messages.messageBody:
Others will be of more help, but your tsuba is signed "HARUTOSHI". It looks
like Soten work, but it is in very sad condition with the entire original
iron surface gone. The fuchi was mass produced Sendai. Supposedly this
work was done by the under-employed samurai of Sendai to augment their
wages. It is Sendai work, but it was handled by a broker in - like - Nagoya
or someplace.
Peter




Peter Bleed
Professor of Anthropology
810 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0368
(402) 472-2439

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Tsuba Information Request
messages.msgSnippet: Hello, I am trying identify a Tsuba I own. I am having difficulty trying to figure out when this Tsuba was made, and what value if any it has. Could anyone
messages.messageBody:
Hello,

I am trying identify a Tsuba I own. I am having difficulty trying to
figure out when this Tsuba was made, and what value if any it has.

Could anyone please provide me with any information about this piece,
I would greatly appreciate it

I have created a web site with photos of the Tsuba at

http://jdb-tsuba.tripod.com/


Thank you for your assistance.
